author: m.kalinin
content: It's not deprecated and is still in the spec. Probably tests doesn't have it because not all clients would respond `ACCEPTED` in those test scenarios

author: funnygiulio
content: ```Payload validation process consists of validating a payload with respect to the block header and execution environment rule sets. ``` little clarification here, does this mean that payload validation do not include execution checks or state root checks?

author: ethlost
content: If hashrate on Ropsten doesn't go up, is there a plan to change TTD again?

author: m.kalinin
content: It does include them, the EE rule set denotes a huge part of YP + changes to the execution environment introduced by all hardforks

author: m.kalinin
content: No, we're expecting EF to increase the hashrate and make the Merge transition happen on June 8th as it is planned

author: ethlost
content: Ah ok, that makes sense

author: robocopsgonemad
content: gm frens. I am working on disconnecting from the PoW after ttd. What disconnect reason are clients using when receiving a p2p status message that contains a total difficulty > the terminal PoW block? Right now was gonna use USELESS_PEER but that seems...... rude

author: robocopsgonemad
content: I feel like subprotocol error is the way to go, but those tend to be vague, and unhelpful to peers

author: stevencook
content: I have a quick q regarding the chosen TTD for ropsten (50000000000000000). This is 3.5x the current difficulty of mainnet (just under ~15000000000000000), is it not? Is there by chance a few 0's too many? I see this morning, the difficulty spiked to just under 100 billion, which is equiv to some ~200 3070 GPUs worth of hash power. To get to the chosen TTD, does the calculation not scale linearly? Which would mean we need 100 million 3070s worth of hashpower?

author: stevencook
content: or does difficulty not grow linearly to applied hashrate?

author: tokey1475
content: its the total difficulty, in other words, the cumulative difficulty of all blocks mined to date

author: stevencook
content: ahh thanks so much for clarifying - i never understood how basing merge on difficulty would even work if we assume hashrate could heavily stall leading into the merge

author: stevencook
content: do you know the geth call to make to get total difficulty? i can look it up

author: stevencook
content:
nevermind, found it:
```
> eth.getBlock(12336171).totalDifficulty
44348765445734085
```
thanks again!
